text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
Revised entire document with updated IT IRM policy and process templates incorporating required internal controls.
This Directive is applicable to all organizations within Internal Revenue Service Information Technology (IRS IT) that provide service and support to IT customers.
Table of Contents
Program Scope and
Background
Purpose
Scope
Authority
Mandate
Management Directive

) Overview - This IRM establishes uniform IT Support Services Management standards for requesting IT support and requests for products and services through the Service Desk. The IRM also deﬁnes the standard processes procedures for recording (open, update, resolve, close), tracking, monitoring and escalating Incidents or Requests for service through the life-cycle via a single enterprise tool/database. (
) Purpose - This IRM establishes uniform Support Services Management standards as it relates to providing support to IT customers while utilizing enterprise tools. (
) Audience - This IRM applies to all Internal Revenue Service (IRS) organiza- tions requesting or providing IT products and services from Information Technology (IT). (
) Policy Owner - Any waivers or deviations of this directive require written approval from the Associate Chief Information Officer, User and Network Services. (
) Program Owner - Information Technology (IT), User and Network Services (UNS), Customer Service Support (CSS) is responsible for the implementation and maintenance of this directive. (

) Primary Stakeholders - Approval of this directive, including updates, rests the IT Chief Technology Officer (CTO) and Associate Chief Information (ACIO) for User and Network Services (UNS). All proposed changes to this directive must be submitted to IT User and Network Services (UNS), Service Support (CSS). (

) Program Goals - The primary objective of IT Support Services Management to return/restore the IT service to users as quickly as possible and minimize the adverse effect on business operations while meeting the Master Service Level Agreement (MSLA). This directive has been created to establish the essential operations deﬁning the function of the Service Desk and Service Support Providers to manage the life-cycle of Incidents and Requests for products and services by way of processes and procedures. (

) This IRM establishes uniform IT Support Services Management standards requesting IT support and requests for products and services through the Service Desk. The IRM also deﬁnes the standard processes and for recording (open, update, resolve, close), tracking, monitoring and Incidents or Requests for service through the life-cycle via a single tool/database. This IRM is to be used by anyone who has the responsibility providing service and support to IT customers. (

) The primary objective of IT Support Services Management is to the IT service to users as quickly as possible and minimize the adverse on business operations while meeting the Master Service Level Agreement (MSLA). This directive has been created to establish the essential deﬁning the function of the Service Desk and Service Support Providers to manage the life-cycle of Incidents and Requests for products and services way of processes and procedures. This IRM has been prepared in with requirements resulting from the IRM restructuring and IRS efforts.
IT Support Services Management Directive
2.148 IT Support Services
) This IRM applies to all Internal Revenue Service (IRS) organizations ing or providing IT products and services from Information Technology (IT). (

) Information Technology (IT), User and Network Services (UNS), Customer Service Support (CSS) is responsible for the development, implementation maintenance of this directive. Approval of this directive, including updates, rests with the IT Chief Technology Officer (CTO) and Associate Chief tion Officer (ACIO) for User and Network Services (UNS). All proposed changes to this directive must be submitted to IT User and Network (UNS), Customer Service Support (CSS). (

) This IRM establishes uniform IT Support Services Management standards requesting IT support and requests for products and services through the Service Desk. The IRM also deﬁnes the standard processes and for recording (open, update, resolve, close), tracking, monitoring and Incidents or Requests for service through the life-cycle via a single tool/database. This IRM is to be used by anyone who has the responsibility providing service and support to IT customers. (

) This IRM establishes the following: a. Uniform Support Services Management standards as it relates to providing support to IT customers while utilizing the enterprise tools. b. The IT support process is deﬁned as the organized approach to docu- menting both the process and the results in support of IT customers single database. IRS management at each site is responsible for ensuring compliance within these standards and to meet the Master Service Level Agreements (MSLA). c. A common workﬂow tool for IT Service Providers is used for reporting and tracking all IT incidents and service requests (i.e., system application software, telecommunications, or hardware) as well as Notiﬁcations, Outages and any related problem documentation.
This IRM applies to all Internal Revenue Service (IRS) organizations request- ing or providing IT products and services from Information Technology (IT).

Uniform Support Services Management standards as it relates to providing support to IT customers while utilizing the enterprise tools. The IT support process is deﬁned as the organized approach to docu

menting both the process and the results in support of IT customers on single database. IRS management at each site is responsible for ensuring compliance within these standards and to meet the Master Service Level Agreements (MSLA). A common workﬂow tool for IT Service Providers is used for reporting and tracking all IT incidents and service requests (i.e., system software, application software, telecommunications, or hardware) as well as Notiﬁcations, Outages and any related problem documentation.

A common workﬂow tool for IT Service Providers is used for reporting and tracking all IT incidents and service requests (i.e., system software, application software, telecommunications, or hardware) as well as Alerts, Notiﬁcations, Outages and any related problem documentation.
